1st level question: Information on the deceased
Notes for translators and interviewers: Important information for assessing cause of death and defining skip pattern.

1st level question: What was the name of the deceased?
Was the deceased female or male?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the sex of the deceased. Either male or female must be selected for every case.

1st level question: Was the deceased male?
2nd level question: Male

1st level question: Was the deceased female?
2nd level question: Female

1st level question: Is date of birth known?
Notes for translators and interviewers: A reliable estimate of age at death must be  obtained for every case. This can either be calculated from known dates of birth and death, or reported as a known age at death. There is no point in proceeding beyond this point if sex and age at death cannot be determined.

2nd level question: When was the deceased born?

1st level question: Is date of death known?

2nd level question: When did (s)he die?
How many years old was (s)he at death?
How many months old was (s)he at death?
How many days old was (s)he at death?
Was (s)he aged 65 years or over at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of the deceased at the time of death. Select this for someone aged 65 years or over at death.

2nd level question: Was (s)he aged 50 to 64 years at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of the deceased at the time of death. Select this for someone aged 50 to 64 years at death.

2nd level question: Was (s)he aged 15-49 years at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of the deceased at the time of death. Select this for someone aged 15-49 years at death.

2nd level question: Was (s)he aged 5 to 14 years at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of the deceased at the time of death. Select this for someone aged 5 to 14 years at death.

2nd level question: Was (s)he aged 1 to 4 years at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of the deceased at the time of death. Select this for someone aged 1 to 4 years at death.

2nd level question: Was (s)he aged 1 to 11 months at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of the deceased at the time of death. Select this for someone aged 1 to 11 months at death.

2nd level question: Was (s)he aged 28 days or less at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of the deceased at the time of death. Select this for someone aged 28 days or less at death.

2nd level question: Did the baby die within 24 hours of birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of a baby at the time of death. Select this for a baby who died within 24 hours of being born.

2nd level question: Did baby die more than 24 hours after but less than 48 hours from birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of a baby at the time of death. Select this for a baby who died more than 24 hours but less than 48 hours of being born.

2nd level question: Did baby die more than 48 hours from birth but within the first week of life?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of a baby at the time of death. Select this for a baby who died more than 48 hours after being born, but within the first week of life.

2nd level question: Did baby die after first week, but within first 28 days?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of a baby at the time of death. Select this for a baby who died after the first week of life, but within the first month.

2nd level question: Was this a woman aged 12 to 19 years at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of a woman who died. Select this category for a woman aged 12 to 19 years at death.

2nd level question: Was this a woman aged 20-34 years at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of a woman who died. Select this category for a woman aged 20 to 34 years at death.

2nd level question: Was this a woman aged 35-49 years at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This can be derived from a general question about the age of a woman who died. Select this category for a woman aged 35 to 49 years at death.

1st level question: Was this a woman who died more than 42 days but less than 1 year after being pregnant or delivering a baby?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman who died more than 42 days but less than 1 year after being pregnant or delivering a baby.

1st level question: What was her/his citizenship/nationality?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the citizenship or nationality of the person who died.

1st level question: Was (s)he a citizen by birth?
Was (s)he a naturalized citizen?
Was (s)he a foreign national?
What was her/his ethnicity?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the ethnicity of the person who died, using locally accepted ethnic groups.

1st level question: What was her/his place of birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record her/his place of birth (country/province/village).

1st level question: What was her/his place of usual residence?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record her/his place of usual residence (country/province/village)..

1st level question: What was her/his place of normal residence 1 to 5 years before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record her/his place of normal residence 1 to 5 years before death (country/province/village)..

1st level question: Where did death occur?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record where the death occurred (country/province/village)..

1st level question: What was the site of death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the site of the death.

1st level question: Did (s)he die in a hospital?
Did (s)he die in another health facility?
Did (s)he die at home?
Did (s)he die in another place?
What was her/his marital status?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the marital status of the person who died.

1st level question: Was the deceased single?
Was the deceased married?
Was the deceased divorced?
Was the deceased widowed?
Was the deceased too young to be married?
What was the date of marriage?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the date of marriage, for a married person.

1st level question: What was the name of the father?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the father's name of the person who died.

1st level question: What was the name of the mother?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the mother's name of the person who died.

1st level question: What was her/his highest level of schooling?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the highest level of schooling for the person who died.

1st level question: Did (s)he have no formal education?
Was her/his highest level of schooling primary school?
Was her/his highest level of schooling secondary school?
Was her/his highest level of schooling higher than secondary school?
Was (s)he able to read and write?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the literacy status of the person who died.

1st level question: What was her/his economic activity status in year prior to death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the main economic activity of the person who died, before they became ill.

1st level question: Was (s)he mainly employed in the year prior to death?
Was (s)he mainly unemployed in the year prior to death?
Was (s)he working as a home.-maker in the year prior to death?
Was (s)he a student in the year prior to death?
Did (s)he live on a pension in the year prior to death?
Did (s)he have another economic activity in the year prior to death?
What was her/his occupation, that is, what kind of work did (s)he mainly do?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the occupation of the person who died.

1st level question: Vital registration and certification
Notes for translators and interviewers: These data allow linkage to vital registration

1st level question: Death registration number/certificate
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the death registration number or certificate number.

1st level question: Date of registration
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the date of registering the death.

1st level question: Place of registration
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the place of registering the death indicating the province/county/city/village and whether this was an urban or rural region.

1st level question: National identification number of deceased
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the National identification number of deceased, if available.

1st level question: Information on the respondent
Notes for translators and interviewers: This information is relevant to quality assurance.

1st level question: Name of VA respondent
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the name of VA respondent.

1st level question: Relationship of respondent to deceased
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the relationship of the VA respondent to the deceased.

1st level question: Is the respondent a parent of the deceased?
Is the respondent a child of the deceased?
Is the respondent another family member of the deceased?
Is the respondent a friend of the deceased?
Is the respondent a health worker?
Is the respondent a public official?
Is the respondent in any other kind of relationship to the deceased?
Did the respondent live with the deceased in the period leading to her/his death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record whether the respondent lived with the deceased.

1st level question: Name of VA interviewer
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the name of VA interviewer.

1st level question: Time at start of interview
Date of interview
Medical history associated with final illness
Was there any diagnosis of Tuberculosis?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of tuberculosis made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of HIV/AIDS?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of HIV or AIDS (including a positive HIV test) made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he have a recent positive test for malaria?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a positive test for malaria within a week of death.

1st level question: Did (s)he have a recent negative test for malaria?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a negative test for malaria within a week of death.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of Measles?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of measles made at some kind of medical facility, within a month of death.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of High Blood pressure?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of hypertension, and may include long-term anti-hypertensive medication, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness. If the hypertension was only diagnosed during pregnancy, this should not be selected.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of heart disease?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of heart disease made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of diabetes?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of diabetes made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of asthma?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of asthma made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of epilepsy?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of epilepsy made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of cancer?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of cancer made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of dementia?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of dementia made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of depression?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of clinical depression, which may have been relevant to the final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of stroke?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of stroke made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of sickle cell disease?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of sickle cell disease made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of kidney disease?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of kidney disease made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Was there any diagnosis of liver disease?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of liver disease made at some kind of medical facility, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he die during the wet season?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select one of these according to local conditions, with wet season covering months of usual rainfall and immediate aftermath, and dry season covering months with no or very little expected rainfall.

1st level question: Did (s)he die during the dry season?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select one of these according to local conditions, with wet season covering months of usual rainfall and immediate aftermath, and dry season covering months with no or very little expected rainfall.

1st level question: For how long was (s)he ill before (s)he died?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the time period that the deceased started feeling ill with onset of symptoms until the time of death.

1st level question: Was (s)he ill for less than 3 weeks before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the final illness lasted less than 3 weeks.

1st level question: Was (s)he ill for 3 weeks or more before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the final illness lasted 3 weeks or more.

1st level question: Did (s)he die suddenly?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this either if the final illness lasted less than a day, or if the final illness seemed to be progressing well and death was not expected.

1st level question: General signs and symptoms associated with final illness
Did (s)he have a fever?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there were any signs of fever during the final illness.

2nd level question: For how long did (s)he have a fever?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the period of time that the deceased had fever during the final illness, continuously or on and off.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have fever for less than 2 weeks before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this is if the fever lasted less than 2 weeks.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have fever for 2 weeks or more before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the fever lasted 2 weeks or more.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have night sweats?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any fever" indicator is selected, select this one if the deceased particularly experienced heavy night sweats.

1st level question: Did (s)he have a cough?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was any cough during the final illness.

2nd level question: For how long did (s)he have a cough?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the duration of cough during the final illness.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have a cough for less than 3 weeks before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the cough lasted less than 3 weeks.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have a cough for 3 weeks or more before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the cough lasted 3 weeks or more.

2nd level question: Was the cough productive, with sputum?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any cough" indicator is selected, select this one if the deceased regularly coughed up sputum or mucus.

2nd level question: Did (s)he cough up blood?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any cough" indicator is selected, select this one if the deceased coughed up blood.

2nd level question: Did (s)he make a whooping sound when coughing?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any cough" indicator is selected, select this one if the deceased experienced paroxysms of coughing associated with the characteristic whooping sound of pertussis. Ideally imitate a whoop as it is difficult to describe. Maybe have a audio recording with you.

1st level question: Did (s)he have any breathing problem?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there were any problems of breathing during the final illness (before the moment of death).

2nd level question: Did (s)he have fast breathing?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any breathing problem" indicator is selected, select this one if the deceased was an infant or child who was breathing much faster than normal.

3rd level question: For how long did (s)he have fast breathing?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the time period that the deceased suffered from breathing much faster than normal during the final illness.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have fast breathing for less than 2 weeks?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the fast breathing lasted for less than 2 weeks.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have fast breathing for 2 weeks or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the fast breathing lasted for 2 weeks or more.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have breathlessness?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the deceased had difficulty breathing and was out of breath during the final illness.

3rd level question: For how long did (s)he have breathlessness?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the time period during the final illness that the deceased had difficulty breathing.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have breathlessness for less than 2 weeks?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the breathlessness lasted for less than 2 weeks.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have breathlessness for 2 weeks or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the breathlessness lasted for 2 weeks or more.

3rd level question: Was (s)he unable to carry out daily routines due to breathlessness?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any breathing problem" indicator is selected, select this one if the deceased found it particularly difficult to breathe when physically active, e.g. walking, going up steps.

3rd level question: Was (s)he breathless while lying flat?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any breathing problem" indicator is selected, select this one if the deceased found it particularly difficult to breathe even when lying down to rest.

2nd level question: Did you see the lower chest wall/ribs being pulled in as the child breathed?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the lower ribs of chest wall on both sides of the chest are pulled in when the child breathes in.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have noisy breathing (grunting or wheezing)?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any breathing problem" indicator is selected, select this one if the deceased was making wheezing sounds as they breathed (or grunting sounds on breathing in small babies).

1st level question: Did (s)he have severe chest pain?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for older children or adults who were experiencing severe pain in their chests, making other activities impossible.

1st level question: Did (s)he have diarrhoea?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was any diarrhoea during the final illness.

2nd level question: For how long did (s)he have diarrhoea?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the time period during which the deceased suffered from diarrhoea.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have diarrhoea for less than 2 weeks?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the diarrhoea lasted for less than 2 weeks.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have diarrhoea for 2 to 4 weeks?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the diarrhoea lasted for 2 to 4 weeks, not necessarily every day.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have diarrhoea for 4 weeks or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the diarrhoea lasted more than 4 weeks, not necessarily every day.

2nd level question: At any time during the final illness was there blood in the stools?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any diarrhoea" indicator is selected, select this one if the diarrhoea contained blood.

1st level question: Did (s)he vomit?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was any vomiting during the final illness.

2nd level question: Did (s)he vomit "coffee grounds" or bright red/blood?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any vomiting" indicator is selected, select this one if the vomit contained blood.  The point is to identify if there was any bleeding of the upper gastrointestinal tract.  Whereas strong and acute bleeding might show as fresh or coagulated blood, less strong bleeding would expose the blood some time to gastric acid, and then it would look like ground coffee (particles of a size between 0.5-2 mm of black or dark brown colour).  In local languages there may be other analogies to describe this kind of presentation of blood.

1st level question: Did (s)he have any abdominal problem?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if any abdominal problem has been present.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have severe abdominal pain?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any abdominal problem" indicator is selected, select this one if severe abdominal pain was present during the final illness.

3rd level question: For how long before death did (s)he have severe abdominal pain?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the time period during the final illness that the deceased suffered from severe abdominal pain.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have severe abdominal pain for less than 2 weeks?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the severe abdominal pain lasted for less than 2 weeks.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have severe abdominal pain for 2 weeks or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the severe abdominal pain lasted for 2 weeks or more.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have a more than usually protruding abdomen?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there is abnormal distension or protrusion of the abdomen. The word abdomen sounds like medical language, and for interviews in English another term might be used to reflect the wording used by the local population, e.g. belly. The best wording here will always depend on the  local language.

3rd level question: For how long did (s)he have a more than usually protruding abdomen?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the time period during the final illness in which the deceased had a more than usual protruding abdomen. The best wording would depend on the local language.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have a more than usually protruding abdomen for less than 2 weeks?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the more than usually protruding abdomen lasted for less than 2 weeks.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have a more than usually protruding abdomen for 2 weeks or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the more than usually protruding abdomen lasted for 2 weeks or more.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have any mass in the abdomen?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any abdominal problem" indicator is selected, select this one if there was mass in the abdomen during the final illness. The abdominal mass would present  as a localized enlargement/swelling in the abdominal area.

3rd level question: For how long did (s)he have the lump inside the abdomen?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the time period during the final illness in which the deceased had a lump inside the abdomen.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have a lump inside the abdomen for less than 2 weeks?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the lump inside the abdomen lasted for less than 2 weeks.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have a lump inside the abdomen for 2 weeks or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the lump inside the abdomen lasted for 2 weeks or more.

1st level question: Did (s)he have a severe headache?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if headache was present during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he have a stiff or painful neck?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if neck stiffness was present in the final illness. This can be characterised by a difficulty in moving the neck.

2nd level question: For how long did (s)he have a stiff or painful neck?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the time period during the final illness during which the deceased suffered from neck pain or stiffness.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have a stiff or painful neck for less than 1 week?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the stiff or painful neck lasted for less than 1 week.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have a stiff or painful neck for 1 week or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the stiff or painful neck lasted for 2 weeks or more.

1st level question: Did (s)he have mental confusion?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects a diagnosis of memory loss or confusion made at some kind of medical facility, or cognitive problems which were evident to the respondent, which may pre-date the deceased's final illness.

2nd level question: For how long did (s)he have mental confusion?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the period of time lasting the symptoms of mental confusion (e.g. loss of orientation, memory loss, loss of ability to focus attention, hallucinations, paranoia, aggressive behaviour).

2nd level question: Did (s)he have mental confusion for 3 months or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the mental confusion lasted for 3 months or more.

1st level question: Was (s)he unconscious for more than 24 hours before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was a coma or unconsciousness for at least the final 24 hours before death, or at an earlier stage of the final illness (possibly with return of consciousness).

2nd level question: Did the unconsciousness start suddenly, quickly (at least within a single day)?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the way the deceased became unconscious.

1st level question: Did (s)he have convulsions?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there were convulsions or fits during the final illness. It should NOT be selected for fits at a much earlier time (in which case consider a possible earlier diagnosis of epilepsy) and should NOT be selected for fits that were only seen during pregnancy (in which case see separate indicator).

2nd level question: For how long did the convulsions last?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the approximate duration in minutes of convulsion episodes suffered by the deceased.

2nd level question: Did the convulsions last for less than 10 minutes?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the convulsions lasted for less than 10 minutes.

2nd level question: Did the convulsions last for 10 minutes or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the convulsions lasted for 10 minutes or more.

2nd level question: Did (s)he become unconscious immediately after the convulsion?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any convulsions or fits" indicator is selected, select this one if the person became unconscious immediately after the convulsions.

1st level question: Did (s)he have any urine problems?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was any problem relating to urine during the final illness.

2nd level question: Did (s)he pass no urine at all?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "any urine problem" is selected and there was no urine produced during at least part of the final illness.

2nd level question: Did (s)he go to urinate more often than usual?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "any urine problem" is selected and urination was much more frequent than normal during the final illness.

2nd level question: During the final illness did (s)he ever pass blood in the urine?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "any urine problem" is selected and the urine contained blood at any time during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he have any skin problems?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was any skin problem during the final illness.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have any ulcers, abscess or sores anywhere except on the feet?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any skin problem" indicator is selected, select this one if there were any ulcers or lesions on the skin, except specifically on the feet.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have any ulcers, abscess or sores on the feet that were not also on other parts of the body?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any skin problem" indicator is selected, select this one if there were any ulcers or lesions exclusively on the feet.

2nd level question: During the illness that led to death, did (s)he have any skin rash?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any skin problem" indicator is selected, select this one if there was any kind of skin rash anywhere on the body, which was not specifically described as measles or herpes zoster (shingles).

3rd level question: For how long did (s)he have the skin rash?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the time period during which the deceased had a skin rash, independent of the type of skin rash.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have the skin rash for less than 1 week?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the skin rash lasted less than 1 week.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have the skin rash for 1 week or more?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the skin rash lasted 1 week or more

3rd level question: Did (s)he have measles rash?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any skin problem" indicator is selected, select this one if the skin problem was described as measles rash.

3rd level question: Did (s)he ever have shingles or herpes zoster?
Notes for translators and interviewers: If the "any skin problem" indicator is selected, select this one if the skin problem was described as herpes zoster or shingles.

1st level question: Did (s)he bleed from the nose, mouth or anus?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was bleeding from the mouth, nose or anus during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he have noticeable weight loss?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if weight loss occurred during the final illness.

2nd level question: Was (s)he severely thin or wasted?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "any weight loss" is selected and the extent of the weight loss was sufficiently serious to amount to severe wasting.

1st level question: Did (s)he have mouth sores or white patches in the mouth or on the tongue?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if oral candidiasis (white spots in the mouth) was present during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he have stiffness of the whole body or was unable to open the mouth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was either rigidity of the body (limbs, neck, etc. not able to move) or if it was not possible to open the mouth (lockjaw) during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he have swelling (puffiness) of the face?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was facial swelling during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he have both feet swollen?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if both feet or ankles or legs were swollen during the final illness - but NOT if only one was swollen, for example following an accident.

1st level question: Did (s)he have any lumps?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was any localised lump or lesion on any part of the body, either at the time of death, or surgically removed prior to death.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have any lumps or lesions in the mouth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this is "any localised lump or lesion" is selected and the lump or lesion was located in the mouth.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have any lumps on the neck?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this is "any localised lump or lesion" is selected and the lump or lesion was located in the neck.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have any lumps on the armpit?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this is "any localised lump or lesion" is selected and the lump or lesion was located in the armpit(s).

2nd level question: Did (s)he have any lumps on the groin?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this is "any localised lump or lesion" is selected and the lump or lesion was located in the groin or genitals.

2nd level question: Did she have an ulcer or swelling in the breast?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this is "any localised lump or lesion" is selected and the lump or lesion was located in the breast - only applies to adult females.

1st level question: Did (s)he have paralysis of one side of the body?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was some degree of paralysis or weakness on one side of the body - possibly affecting the face (maybe causing difficulties in swallowing or talking) or arms/hands or legs/feet.

1st level question: Did (s)he have difficulty or pain while swallowing liquids?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was difficulty or pain in swallowing liquids during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he have yellow discoloration of the eyes?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the white parts of the deceased's eyes had turned distinctly yellow in colour (and possibly yellow soles of the feet for small babies).

1st level question: Did her/his hair colour change to reddish or yellowish?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was an abnormal change in hair colour - possibly becoming reddish or paler - during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he look pale (thinning/lack of blood) or have pale palms, eyes or nail beds?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if either blood test results indicated anaemia or low haemoglobin levels, or if the person was unusually pale (inner eyelids, palms of hands, soles of feet) during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he have sunken eyes?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the eyes were unusually sunken into the face during the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he drink a lot more water than usual?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person drank a lot more water than usual during the final illness.

1st level question: Did she have excessive vaginal bleeding in between menstrual periods?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had vaginal bleeding in between menstrual periods.

1st level question: Did her vaginal bleeding stopped naturally during menopause?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman (probably aged 40 years or over) whose normal vaginal bleeding (menstrual periods) had stopped naturally.

1st level question: Did she have vaginal bleeding after menopause?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman (probably aged 40 years or over) whose normal vaginal bleeding had stopped naturally, but who later experienced further vaginal bleeding (not menstrual periods).

1st level question: Signs and symptoms associated with pregnancy

Threshold values: only one of the questions 3C100-130 can be answered with "yes"
1st level question: Was she neither pregnant, nor delivered, within 6 weeks of her death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was reported not to have been pregnant or to have delivered within 6 weeks of her death

Threshold values: only one of the questions 3C100-130 can be answered with "yes"
1st level question: Was she pregnant at the time of death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was reported to have been pregnant at the time of her death. This means that a foetus, either at an early stage of pregnancy or nearer full term, remained inside her body at the time of death. This includes a woman who dies undelivered during labour.

Threshold values: only one of the questions 3C100-130 can be answered with "yes"
1st level question: Did she die within 6 weeks of giving birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was reported to have delivered a baby within 6 weeks of her death. This means one or more potentially viable babies, born either dead or alive, were delivered in the previous 6 weeks.

Threshold values: only one of the questions 3C100-130 can be answered with "yes"
1st level question: Did she die within 6 weeks of a pregnancy that lasted less than 6 months?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was reported to have been at an early stage (first 6 months) of pregnancy within 6 weeks of her death, but the pregnancy had ended in a spontaneous or induced abortion at a stage before the foetus was viable.

2nd level question: Did she die within 24 hours after delivery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was reported to have delivered a baby and then died within 24 hours of the delivery.

2nd level question: Did she die during labour, but undelivered?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was reported to have been pregnant at the time of her death, who had gone into labour, and who died before a baby was delivered.

2nd level question: Was she breastfeeding at death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was reported to have been breast-feeding her youngest child at the time of her final illness.

2nd level question: How many births, including stillbirths, did she/the mother have before this baby?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the number of births this woman had before the present one (twins count as one birth in this context)

2nd level question: Was this the woman's first pregnancy?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was reported to have been pregnant for the first time.

2nd level question: Did she have four or more births, including stillbirths, before this pregnancy?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who before any current pregnancy had 4 (including stillbirths) or more pregnancies, or who died during her current pregnancy, or within 6 weeks of her current pregnancy ending.

2nd level question: Did she have any previous Caesarean section?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had delivered a baby by Caesarean section in any of her previous pregnancies.

2nd level question: Did she die during or after a multiple pregnancy?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who died while pregnant with twins (or triplets, etc.) or within 6 weeks of a multiple pregnancy ending.

2nd level question: During pregnancy, did she suffer from high blood pressure?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was diagnosed with high blood pressure specifically during her pregnancy.

2nd level question: Did she have foul smelling vaginal discharge during pregnancy or after delivery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was known to have had a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, either during pregnancy, or  after delivery.

2nd level question: During the last 3 months of pregnancy, did she suffer from convulsions?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was known to have had fits specifically during her pregnancy.

2nd level question: During the last 3 months of pregnancy did she suffer from blurred vision?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was known to have had blurred vision specifically during her pregnancy.

2nd level question: Did she give birth to a live, healthy baby within 6 weeks of death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was reported to have delivered a live, healthy baby within 6 weeks of her death.

2nd level question: Was there excessive vaginal bleeding during pregnancy or after delivery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who experienced excessive vaginal bleeding around pregnancy and delivery.

3rd level question: Was there vaginal bleeding during the first 6 months of pregnancy?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years with excessive vaginal bleeding during the first 6 months of pregnancy.

3rd level question: Was there vaginal bleeding during the last 3 months of pregnancy but before labour started?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had excessive vaginal bleeding before labour started.

3rd level question: Was there excessive vaginal bleeding during labour?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had excessive vaginal bleeding during labour.

3rd level question: Was there excessive vaginal bleeding after delivering the baby?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had excessive vaginal bleeding after the delivery of a baby.

2nd level question: Was the placenta not completely delivered?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was known to have had problems delivering her placenta after her baby was born, with part or all of the placenta remaining inside.

2nd level question: Did she deliver or try to deliver an abnormally positioned baby?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had recently delivered or tried to deliver an abnormally positioned baby, e.g. a breech presentation.

2nd level question: Was she in labour for unusually long (more than 24 hours)?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was known to have had well-established labour for 24 hours or more, irrespective of the final outcome of that labour.

2nd level question: Did she attempt to terminate the pregnancy?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was known to have been recently pregnant and had attempted, with or without succeeding, to terminate her pregnancy.

2nd level question: Did she recently have a pregnancy that ended in an abortion (spontaneous or induced)?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was known to have been recently pregnant and had the pregnancy terminated, via a spontaneous abortion or an induced abortion.

2nd level question: Did she give birth in a health facility?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was delivered or delivered recently at a health facility. This question is repeated for neonatal deaths with a slightly different wording.

2nd level question: Did she give birth at home?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a  woman aged 12-50 years who was delivered or delivered recently at home or on the way to another place.  This question is repeated for neonatal deaths with a slightly different wording.

2nd level question: Did she give birth elsewhere, e.g. on the way to a facility?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who was delivered or delivered recently somewhere other than a health facility or at home, for example while travelling to seek care.  This question is repeated for neonatal deaths with a slightly different wording.

2nd level question: Did she receive professional assistance during the delivery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had delivered recently and been attended by a medical professional (doctor, nurse or midwife).

2nd level question: Did she have an operation to remove her uterus shortly before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had a hysterectomy, probably as an emergency obstetric intervention, shortly before she died.

2nd level question: Did she have a normal vaginal delivery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 who had a normal delivery, without the assistance of forceps/vacuum or through a caesarean section.

2nd level question: Did she have an assisted delivery, with forceps/vacuum?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had delivered recently with assistance by means of forceps or a vacuum device.

2nd level question: Did she deliver by Caesarean section?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman aged 12-50 years who had delivered recently by means of a Caesarean section.

2nd level question: Was the baby born more than one month early?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a woman age 12-50 years who delivered a baby a month or more before the expected date.

1st level question: Neonatal/child history, signs and symptoms
Was the child part of a multiple  birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a baby who was born as one of a multiple pregnancy.

1st level question: Was the child born in a complicated delivery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a baby who was born in a complicated delivery, for example lasting a long time or needing special assistance.

1st level question: Was the baby born 24 hours or more after the water broke?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate that was born more than 24 hours after the mother's waters broke.

1st level question: Did the baby stop moving in the womb before labour started?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate if the mother could feel that her baby had stopped moving inside her womb before the time her labour began.

1st level question: Was baby born in a normal vaginal delivery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who was born in a normal vaginal delivery.

1st level question: Was baby born with forceps/vacuum?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who was born with assistance by means of forceps or a vacuum device.

1st level question: Was baby delivered by Caesarean section?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who was born by means of a Caesarean section.

1st level question: Did the baby's bottom, feet, arm or hand come into the vagina before its head?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate that was born from an abnormal (e.g. breech) position. The abnormally positioned baby may have been delivered through the vagina, or the abnormal position might have led to a Caesarean section. If it was a Caesarean birth, it doesn’t matter which part of the baby came out first through the abdomen.

1st level question: Was the baby of abnormal size?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate or infant that seemed to be of abnormal size and weight at birth.

2nd level question: Was the baby smaller than normal, weighing under 2.5 kg?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate and child under 1 year of age that seemed very small, or was weighed and found to be less than 2.5 kg, at birth.

2nd level question: Was the baby larger than normal, weighing over 4.5 kg?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate that was too big for an uncomplicated deliver, or was weighed and found to be more than 4.5 kg, at birth.

1st level question: How many weeks was the pregnancy when the baby was born?
Notes for translators and interviewers: This reflects the duration of the pregnancy from which the dead child was born.

1st level question: Had the pregnancy lasted less than 34 weeks when the baby was born?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a pregnancy which lasted for less than 34 weeks.

1st level question: Had the pregnancy lasted between 34 and 37 weeks when the baby was born?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a pregnancy which lasted between 34 and 37 weeks.

1st level question: Had the pregnancy lasted more than 37 weeks when the baby was born?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a pregnancy which lasted more than 37 weeks, i.e. nearly or at full term for the birth.

1st level question: Was the umbilical cord wrapped several times (more than once) around the neck of the child at birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate that was born with its cord wrapped several times (more than once) around its neck.

1st level question: Did the baby/the child have any noticeable malformation?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a baby or young child who was born with obvious malformations of any kind - this may include diagnosed malformations of internal organs, for example heart defects.

2nd level question: Did the baby/the child have a swelling/defect on the back?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "any congenital malformations" is selected and there is any swelling or defect on the baby's back.

2nd level question: Did the baby/the child have a very large head?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "any congenital malformations" is selected and the baby was born with a very large head.

2nd level question: Did the baby/the child have a very small head?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "any congenital malformations" is selected and the baby was born with a very small head.

1st level question: Was the baby/the child not growing normally?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a baby or young child who did not seem to be growing and developing in a way that was normal for his or her age.

1st level question: Was the baby blue in colour at birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who was blue in colour, cyanosed.

1st level question: Did the baby cry after birth, even if only a little bit?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who cried, even if just a little, after birth.

1st level question: Did the baby breathe after birth, even a little?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who was able to breath after birth.

1st level question: Was the baby given assistance to breathe at birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who needed assistance to breath after birth.

1st level question: If the baby did not cry or breathe, was it born dead?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate that never cried, moved or breathed after it was delivered - and so was stillborn.

2nd level question: Was the dead baby macerated, that is, showed signs of decay?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a stillborn baby whose skin was puffy or mushy.

1st level question: Was the baby able to suckle or bottle-feed within the first 24 hours  after birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who was healthy and feeding within the first 24 hours from birth.

2nd level question: Did the baby stop suckling or bottle feeding 3 days after birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who initially fed well, but stopped sucking 3 days or more after birth.

1st level question: Did the baby have convulsions starting within the first day of life?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who had convulsions in the first 24 hours after birth.

1st level question: Did the baby have convulsions starting on the second day or later after birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who had convulsions 48 hours or more after birth.

1st level question: Did the baby's body become stiff, with the back arched backwards?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who became rigid and whose back was bent backwards.

1st level question: Did the child have a bulging or raised fontanelle?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a baby whose fontanelle (soft spot on top of the head) was raised or bulging during the final illness.

1st level question: Did the child have a sunken fontanelle?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a baby whose fontanelle (soft spot on top of the head) was sunken or depressed during the final illness.

1st level question: Did the baby become unresponsive or unconscious soon after birth (within less than 24 hours)?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who became unconscious or unresponsive after less than 24 hours from birth.

1st level question: Did the baby become unresponsive or unconscious more than 1 day after birth?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who became unconscious or unresponsive after more than 1 day from birth.

1st level question: Did the baby become cold to the touch before it died?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who felt very cold before death.

1st level question: Did the baby have redness or discharge from the umbilical cord stump?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who had red or pussy signs of infection around the umbilicus before death.

1st level question: Did the baby have yellow palms or soles?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who had yellowing of the skin of their palms or soles.

1st level question: Did the mother NOT receive tetanus toxoid (TT) vaccine?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the baby's mother had not been vaccinated against tetanus during or before her pregnancy.

1st level question: How many births, including stillbirths, did the baby's mother have before this baby?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Record the number of previous pregnancies for the neonate's mother

1st level question: Was this baby born from the mother's first pregnancy?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died, and who was born from the mother's first pregnancy.

1st level question: Did the mother have 4 or more births before this baby was born?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died, and whose mother had had four or more previous pregnancies.

1st level question: During pregnancy, did the baby's mother suffer from high blood pressure?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died, and whose mother was diagnosed with high blood pressure during her pregnancy.

1st level question: Did the baby's mother have foul smelling vaginal discharge during pregnancy or after delivery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died, and whose mother was known to have had a foul-smelling vaginal discharge, either during pregnancy, or after delivery.

1st level question: During the last 3 months of pregnancy, did the baby's mother suffer from convulsions?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died, and whose mother was known to have had fits specifically during her pregnancy.

1st level question: During the last 3 months of pregnancy did the baby's mother suffer from blurred vision?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died, and whose mother was known to have had blurred vision specifically during her pregnancy.

1st level question: Did the baby's mother have vaginal bleeding during the last 3 months of pregnancy but before labour started?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died, and whose mother had excessive vaginal bleeding before her labour started.

1st level question: Was the child born in a health facility?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died after being delivered at a health facility.

1st level question: Was the child born at home?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died after being delivered at home.

1st level question: Was the child born somewhere else, e.g. on the way to a facility?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died after being delivered somewhere other than at a health facility or at home, for example while travelling to seek care.

1st level question: Did the mother receive professional assistance during the delivery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this for a neonate who died, and whose delivery was attended by a medical professional (doctor, nurse or midwife).

1st level question: History of injuries/accidents
Did (s)he suffer from any injury or accident that led to her/his death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there was any kind of injury or accident associated with the final illness.

2nd level question: Was it a road traffic accident?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and it occurred in a road accident of some kind (e.g. as passenger, driver, cyclist, pedestrian).

3rd level question: Was (s)he injured as a pedestrian/walking?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and if "road traffic accident" is also selected and it occurred while the deceased was walking.

3rd level question: Was (s)he injured as an occupant of a car vehicle?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and if "road traffic accident" is also selected and it occurred while the deceased was inside a vehicle/car.

3rd level question: Was (s)he injured as an occupant of a bus or heavy transport vehicle?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and if "road traffic accident" is also selected and it occurred while the deceased was inside a vehicle (bus, heavy transport).

3rd level question: Was (s)he injured as a driver or passenger of a motorcycle?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and if "road traffic accident" is also selected and it occurred while the deceased was on a motorcycle either as the driver or a passenger.

3rd level question: Was (s)he injured as a pedal cyclist?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and if "road traffic accident" is also selected and it occurred while the deceased was riding a bike.

3rd level question: Do you know anything about the counter-part that was hit during the road traffic accident?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Do you know anything about the counter-part that was hit during the road traffic accident?
Was it a pedestrian?
Was it a stationary object?
Was it a car vehicle?

4th level question: Was it a bus or heavy transport vehicle?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Was it a bus or heavy transport vehicle?
Was it a motorcycle?
Was it a pedal cycle?
Was it something else?

2nd level question: Was (s)he Injured in a non-road transport accident?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and it occurred in a road transport accident NOT on a road (boat, train, aeroplane, etc.).

2nd level question: Was (s)he Injured in a fall?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and it occurred as a result of falling (but NOT falling into water and drowning, and NOT falling into a fire and burning).

2nd level question: Did (s)he die of drowning?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and it occurred as a result of drowning in water.

2nd level question: Did (s)he suffer from burns?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and it occurred as a result of being burnt in a fire or otherwise exposed to extreme heat.

2nd level question: Did (s)he suffer from any plant/ animal/insect bite or sting  that led to her/his death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and it occurred as a result of being bitten or stung by a poisonous animal (snake, scorpion, etc.).

3rd level question: Was it a dog?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and if "animal/insect bite" is selected and it occurred as a result of being bitten/attacked by a dog.

3rd level question: Was it a snake?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and if "animal/insect bite" is selected and it occurred as a result of being bitten/attacked by a snake.

3rd level question: Was it an insect?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and if "animal/insect bite" is selected and it occurred as a result of being bitten/stung by an insect.

2nd level question: Was (s)he injured by a force of nature?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and it occurred as a result of an external event (earthquake, volcano, flood, etc.).

2nd level question: Was there any poisoning?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and it occurred as a result of ingesting or being injected with some kind of poisonous material (weed killer, insecticide, non-prescribed drugs, etc.), but NOT as a result of a poisonous bite or sting.

2nd level question: Was (s)he subject to violence/assault?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and the injury occurred as a result of a deliberate action by another person, either as a personal attack or during a war or other outbreak of violence  - this can be selected in addition to one of the previous indicators about the mode of injury.

2nd level question: Was the injury intentionally inflicted by someone else?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the deceased suffered from an injury intentionally infection by someone else.

3rd level question: Was (s)he injured by a fire arm?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the deceased suffered from an injury caused by a fire arm (e.g. pistols and rifles).

3rd level question: Was (s)he injured from a stab, cut or pierce?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the deceased suffered from a stab, cut or pierce wound.

3rd level question: Was (s)he injured by machinery?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the deceased suffered from an injury caused by machines or parts of a machine.

3rd level question: Was (s)he struck by an animal or object?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the deceased suffered from an injury caused by an animal or object thrown at them.

2nd level question: Do you think (s)he committed suicide?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "recent injury or accident" is selected and it is thought to have occurred as a result of a deliberate action by the person who died - this can be selected in addition to one of the previous indicators about the mode of injury.

1st level question: Risk factors
Did (s)he drink alcohol?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died was a regular and sometimes excessive drinker of alcohol up to the time of the final illness.

1st level question: Did (s)he smoke tobacco (cigarette, cigar, pipe, etc.)?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died was a regular smoker up to the time of the final illness. (make sure you ask for cigarette, cigar, pipe, etc. and not just "smoking").

1st level question: Health service utilisation
Was (s)he adequately vaccinated?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died had been adequately vaccinated in relation to their age - for a child this information may be available from a health card, but also directly from the VA respondent. "Adequately vaccinated" means that the person had received most of the vaccines appropriate for them.

1st level question: Did (s)he receive any treatment for the illness that led to death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died obtained treatment from a health facility during their final illness (either out-patient or admitted).

2nd level question: Did (s)he receive oral rehydration salts?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "treatment for final illness" is selected and the person who died had been given oral rehydration therapy during their final illness.

2nd level question: Did (s)he receive (or need) intravenous fluids (drip) treatment?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "treatment for final illness" is selected and the person who died had received treatment through an IV drip during their final illness.

2nd level question: Did (s)he receive (or need) a blood transfusion?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if any blood transfusion was recommended, prescribed or received during the final illness. Do select it if a blood transfusion was prescribed, even if blood was not available or not affordable, and so was not actually given.

2nd level question: Did (s)he receive (or need) treatment/food through a tube passed through the nose?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "treatment for final illness" is selected and the person who died had received treatment through an IV drip during their final illness.

2nd level question: Did (s)he receive (or need) injectable antibiotics?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if any intravenous (e.g. by drip or injection) or intramuscular (by injection) antibiotics were recommended, prescribed or taken during the final illness. Do select it if antibiotics were prescribed, even if they were not available or not affordable, and so were not actually taken.

2nd level question: Did (s)he have (or need) an operation for the illness?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if "treatment for final illness" is selected and any surgical procedures were performed during the course of the final illness.

3rd level question: Did (s)he have the operation within 1 month before death?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if any surgical procedures were performed during the last month of the final illness.

2nd level question: Was (s)he discharged from hospital very ill?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person had been admitted to hospital during the final illness, and was then sent home in the expectation that they would not recover.

1st level question: Background and context
In the final days before death, did  (s)he travel to a hospital or health facility?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died travelled to a hospital ( or health facility offering a 24-hour service) during the final illness.  The main concept is “hospital” which by definition is a 24/7 service. But in some countries there are smaller facilities which are not hospitals, but do offer 24/7 services, so those are included– but not lesser facilities which have no emergency service.

2nd level question: Did  (s)he use motorised transport to get to the hospital or health facility?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died travelled to a hospital or health facility by means of motorised transport (car, truck, tractor, motorcycle, scooter or ambulance) during the final illness.

2nd level question: Were there any problems during admission to the hospital or health facility?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died travelled to a hospital or health facility, and then had problems on arrival (delays, paperwork, queues, no staff).

2nd level question: Were there any problems with the way  (s)he was treated (medical treatment, procedures, inter-personal attitudes, respect, dignity) in the hospital or health facility?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died travelled to a hospital or health facility, and then had problems with how they were treated (medical treatment, procedures, inter-personal attitudes, respect, dignity).

2nd level question: Were there any problems getting medications,  or diagnostic tests in the hospital or health facility?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died travelled to a hospital or health facility, and then had problems obtaining essential items (drugs, medications or other prescriptions, blood products, and/or diagnostic tests such as lab tests and x-rays, either within the facility or needing to be bought elsewhere).

1st level question: Does it take more than 2 hours to get to the nearest hospital or health facility from the deceased's household?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the person who died lived in a household from where it would reasonably take more than 2 hours to reach the nearest 24-hour health facility by the means of transport available to the household members.

1st level question: In the final days before death, were there any doubts about whether medical care was needed?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if there were doubts among those assisting in the final illness (family members, etc.) about whether the final illness was sufficiently serious to need treatment at a health facility.

1st level question: In the final days before death, was traditional medicine used?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if a major part of treatment for the final illness was provided by any kind of traditional or alternative practitioner (herbal remedies, massages, drinks, foods, amulets, spells or blessings provided by traditional healers, witch doctors or shaman).

1st level question: In the final days before death, did anyone use a telephone or cell phone to call for help?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if a telephone of any kind (working landline, or cell phone charged and with credit) was used by those assisting in the final 24 hours of the illness for example to call  for help or arrange transportation.

1st level question: Over the course of illness, did the total costs of care and treatment prohibit other household payments?
Notes for translators and interviewers: Select this if the total costs incurred in the final illness were sufficiently great to mean that other kinds of household expenses (food, fuel, travel, education etc.) could not be met, or caused debt or sale of household assets.

1st level question: Optional open narrative
Any comments that may provide additional information.
Notes for translators and interviewers: Recording this information may be helpful to assess the diagnosis in cases where software assessment of the diagnosis may not deliver reliable results and physician review is necessary.   Its use is optional.
